TaxonomicNotes.value: Two distinct subspecies are recognized, Chioglossa lusitanica lusitanica and C. l. longipes (Arntzen et al. 2007).

The currently accepted taxonomy recognizes two subspecies: the whitish, depigmented and blind Proteus anguinus anguinus (“White Proteus”), and the dark-colored, eyed P. a. parkelj (“Black Proteus”). The subspecies P. a. parkelj was considered to be of doubtful validity (Goricki and Trontelj 2006).

The White Proteus is distributed throughout the entire range of the species, the Black Proteus is only known from a few sites in the region of Bela Krajina in southeastern Slovenia.

Recent molecular studies revealed that the species is deeply subdivided into nine lineages supported by both mitochondrial DNA and microsatellites (Gorički and Trontelj 2006, Trontelj et al. 2009, Trontelj and Zakšek 2016, Vörös et al. 2019). The Black Proteus constitutes one of those lineages. Their ranges are mostly allopatric, although they are touching or even overlapping in some areas (Gorički et al. 2017).

The assessment of the exact taxonomic and conservation status of the Proteus lineages is the subject of ongoing research (Bizjak Mali and Sket 2019), but they should be treated as evolutionary significant units, to ensure the survival of diversity in this threatened species.

Four subspecies have been described: Salamandra atra atra; S. a. aurorae; S. a. prenjensis; and S. a. pasobiensis. The status of these subspecies remains questionable. S. a. prenjensis is often not considered to be valid. S. a. aurorae has been sometimes considered to be a separate species. Joger (1996), using serum proteins, showed significant differences, and he proposed the elevation of S. a. aurorae to a full species. Veith et al. (1998), analyzing mitDNA of S. a. aurorae did not find any significant difference. Riberon et al. (2001) indicate a complex pattern of divergence for the alpine populations, without reaching or stressing any taxonomic consequences.

The exact ranges of members of the Triturus cristatus superspecies are unclear in the central Balkans because of narrow or extensive areas of hybridization. Two isolated subspecies have been described, occurring to the east and west of the Iron Gates of the Danube.
This is a broader concept of this species including formerly separated Hyla perrini (Dufresnes et al. 2018), now again recognized as subspecies of H. intermedia (Dufresnes et al. 2021).

The name Rana balcanica Schneider and Sinsch, 1992 is occasionally used, but this is a junior synonym of Pelophylax kurtmuelleri (Dubois and Ohler 1994).

The species status of P. kurtmuelleri is controversial (Speybroeck et al. 2010, 2020), mostly due to its low mtDNA divergence and shared interspecific polymorphism with P. ridibundus (e.g., Lymberakis et al. 2007, Akin et al. 2010, Plötner et al. 2012, Hofman et al. 2015, Litvinchuk et al. 2020) and weak morphometric differentiation (Papežík et al. 2021). The taxon was thus considered conspecific with P. ridibundus by Speybroeck et al. (2010) and Sindaco and Razzetti (2021).
We follow Carranza and Amat (2005) in transferring this species from Euproctus to the genus Calotriton.

The Carpathian Newt (Lissotriton montandoni) has been confirmed to be a closely related sister species to Lissotriton vulgaris and a member of the proposed Smooth Newt or Lissotriton vulgaris species complex or group (Litvinchuk et al. 2005, Wielstra et al. 2018).
Dufresnes et al. (2019) revised the taxonomy of the B. viridis complex, synonymizing B. balearicus and Bufo variabilis within it.

There is ongoing debate about the distinctiveness between this species and Bombina pachypus (e.g. Hofman et al. 2007, Speybroeck et al. 2010, Fijarczyk et al. 2011). Bombina pachypus was synonymized with this species by Pabijan et al. (2013), however, consider this taxon as an incipient species.

We follow multiple European checklists (e.g. Speybroeck et al. 2010, Sillero et al. 2014, Speybroeck et al. 2020) and retain B. pachypus as a synonym of this species and should be considered valid at subspecies level (B.v. pachypus). Frost (2022) also treats B. pachypus as a synonym.
Elevated from subspecies level of Lissotriton vulgaris by Dubois and Raffaëlli (2009), validated by Wielstra et al. (2018).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Lissotriton graecus, L. kosswigi and L. lantzi (Dubois and Raffaëlli 2009).

L. schmidtleri, assigned as a separate species by Pabijanet al. 2017 and Wielstra et al. (2018), has been recognized as a subspecies of L. vulgaris by Taxonomic Committee of Societas Europaea Herpetologica, who require more information on contact zones between L. v. schmidtleri and L. v. vulgaris before the species rank of schmidtleri can be accepted, and maintain both L. v. schmidtleri and L. v. lantzi, as subspecies of L. vulgaris (Speybroeck et al. 2020). However, this assessment follows Amphibian Species of the World (Frost 2021) in recognising both L. schmidtleri and L. lantzi as valid species.
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Lissotriton maltzani (Sequiera et al. 2020, Speybroeck et al. 2020).
This was previously considered a subspecies of Hyla arborea, until it was elevated to species status by Stöck et al. (2008).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this, Hyla molleri and H. orientalis, which were both elevated from subspecies level (Stöck et al. 2008).

Triturus cristatus was formerly considered to include four subspecies: T. cristatus cristatus; T. cristatus dobrogicus; T. cristatus karelinii; and T. cristatus carnifex. These are now recognized as separate species under the Triturus cristatus superspecies. On the basis of results of molecular genetic analyses, Triturus carnifex has been split into Triturus carnifex s.l. and Triturus macedonicus.
This is a split from the broader concept of Pelodytes punctatus (Díaz-Rodríguez et al. 2017).
taxonomicAuthority: Díaz-Rodríguez, Gehara, Márquez, Vences, Gonçalves, Sequeira, Martínez-Solano & Tejedo, 2017

TaxonomicNotes.value: This is a split from the broader concept of Pelobates syriacus (Dufresnes et al. 2019).
This is a split from Rana temporaria, where it was previously considered a subspecies (Dufresnes et al. 2020).
Discoglossus jeanneae has been synonymized under this species by Dufresnes et al. (2020).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Alytes almogavarii, which was previously considered to be a subspecies (Dufresnes and Martínez-Solano 2020).
This is a split from the broader concept of Alytes obstetricans, for which it was previously considered to be a subspecies (Dufresnes and Martínez-Solano 2020).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Pelobates vespertinus, which has been removed from synonymy of this species (Litvinchuk et al. 2013, Suryadnaya 2014).

Following genetic analysis, some subpopulations from Russia and those from Kazakhstan have now been assigned to Pelobates vespertinus which had been removed from synonymy of this species (Suryadnaya 2014). There is a hybrid zone in northeastern Ukraine and the Russian province of Kursk between the range of this species and P. vespertinus.

This account follows the suggested Salamandra monophyletic group distribution presented in Steinfartz et al. (2000). See also Burgon et al. (2021).

The identity of some subpopulations of Salamandra species reported from western Anatolia (Türkiye) require further investigation and are not included within this concept, although Frost (2022) notes that it is expected to occur there.
We follow Mattoccia et al. (2005) and Canestrelli et al. (2006) in separating Salamandrina perspicillata from S. terdigitata.

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Pelodytes atlanticus (Díaz-Rodríguez et al. 2017). It was thought that subpopulations in low and mid-elevation montane areas of eastern and central Spain did actually belong to P. hespericus (Díaz-Rodríguez et al. 2017), however the two species are thought to be conspecific (Dufresnes et al. 2020).

Some of the subpopulations north of the Alps, in Austria and Germany, show degrees of hybridization with Triturus cristatus and with T. dobrogicus (Mačát et al. 2019, Wielstra et al. 2021). Triturus carnifex is not included in the German list as all subpopulations there are considered hybrids (Fahrbach et al 2021).

The exact ranges of members of the Triturus cristatus superspecies are unclear in the central Balkans. The former subspecies macedonicus has been split off as a separate species following Arntzen et al. (2007).
